reviewText:
Aesthetically this game is fantastic! It has it's own unique and compelling art style, easy to understand and fun gameplay and of course, a great music to tie it all together while you are swearing at your friend!

Each time you complete a level or game with our friend, you gain exp and the ability to unlock characters, levels etc. Which will soon get you hooked!

It's a great party game, I played it with only one other friend but I can imagine the chaos of trying to hold my own in a 4 player game (the good kind of chaos, of course!)

I would definitely recommend this game, especially if you and your friends enjoy screaming at each other.
voteText: 22 of 23 people (96%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wand Wars is an frantic arena-brawling game for both single and multiplayer, where you have to catch and toss a killer orb at your opponents while trying not to get turned into a chicken.

The orb mechanism is easy to grasp and you'll be an expert in no time. Press a button when the orb is close and you capture it for a short time, giving you just enough time to aim and fire it at the nearest opponent. Once fired, the orb just keeps going, bouncing off walls. As the match proceeds, the orb gets larger and faster.

It's about timing, basically - hitting the button just before you get smashed in the face, then turning the tables on whoever threw it. With the full 4 players, it's pure twitch gaming.

Wand Wars gameplay review video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IrBZzu1F23o

On its own, that would be a decent but limited game. But your second ability is to fire black arrows. If you hit an opponent, they briefly turn into a chicken, whose only ability is to run away. The arrow can also be used to neutralise the orb, making it slow and harmless until next caught.

Together, these two things add an element of strategy to your attacks, although nothing complex or clever. The only way to really add strategy to the game is to play in teams, 2 vs 2. So perhaps one player would be on chicken duty, the other orb. Or you could pass the orb between you (you can only harm enemies when firing the orb), and only strike when the time is right.

Powerups are sometimes added to the arena (and you can optionally start with some in Versus). They're massively powered deadly attacks of different kind, and can turn the game into chaos as everyone tries to fire them off at once. When you fire them, the game pauses for a couple of second for an animation, which can get tiring!

The singleplayer Story Mode is split into the stories of six unlockable characters, each consisting of several matches. Each match has something unique about it - number of players, teams, weird levels with moving walls, different game types etc - so it never gets dull.

Versus Mode consists of single, customisable 1-4 player matches (including however many bots), with a choice of 5 game types. This includes the basic battle type, a type where your team has to get the orb into the opponent's goal, and more.

Pleasingly, Wand Wars works well in singleplayer. The bots are well programmed in the basics (with multiple difficulty levels), so it doesn't feel like you're not really playing the game properly. They're not so clever at guarding the goal in that game type, but that's a team-focused game and should really be saved for humans.

Wand Wars feels slick, it's easy to learn and not difficult to master. Pulling off a good move is very satisfying - stuff like turning an opponent into a chicken just as you're about to grab the orb, then bouncing it off the wall into their stupid clucking face.

The limited strategic potential means this game will have an exciting but fairly brief life in your library, but if you have a good local multiplayer scene going, it'll fit happily into the rotation. And if you play it singleplayer, the Story Mode keeps changing things up enough for you to want to keep going.

* Version reviewed: 13 April 2016 build
* More indie gaming videos by Randomise User

reviewText:
*Review copy was provided in order to review the game on launch day*

To understand what the game is by comparing it to another, think Lethal League but in a top-down perspective and no character specific abilities.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ASpDDvv4uzY

The art style is great, the music is nice and up-beat, combine that with the awesome gameplay of you hitting a magical ball that gets faster and larger as it gets smacked back and forth by you & your enemy, until one of you gets hit and you're out!

There's a handful of modes, levels, characters, powerups that you can pick up, and up to 4 players in one match be it bots or with your friends (locally. No online multiplayer sadly).

Was keeping an eye on this game for a while but never got that excited for it until I've played it and played a lot of matches. It's really fun and planning to play more of it in short bursts.

reviewText:
A charming game with really great local multiplayer!
It's a mix between Towerfall and Lethal League, but different enough to be something new.

- Simple gameplay, but with a good amount of depth to it
- Multiple game modes
- Great art and sound
- Power-ups and character unlocks

I highly recommend this game if you want to play locally with friends. It does have a singleplayer campaign if you want to play alone (haven't played it yet), but I think that the real worth is in bringing some friends over and having a great time. If that's what you wanna do, this game is for you.

reviewText: Wand Wars has easy to learn but hard to master gameplay, fantastic local multiplayer action, a challenging single player mode, and some of the best game feel I've ever experienced. Every button you press feels impactful and juicy, and timing is everything. Local multiplayer is where this game truly shines, but even if you don't have a group of friends to meet up and play games with, imo it's well worth the price to check out the story mode and play some bot matches. Even when you're playing with the AI things can get pretty intense. I've logged about 4 hours total so far (probably more than half of that in single player) and I feel like I still have a lot of improving to do before I'm good enough to take on the top level bots and the final stages of the story mode - but I get a little better every time I play! Make sure you play with a controller for the best experience, and make sure you play with the volume up, as the music and sound design is also top notch.

reviewText:
This is how I see wand wars. I've played quake for quite a few years now and it's a hard game. Wand wars gives you that same feeling. It can be casual and fun with your friends but, also very intense and skillful. If you love to game vs your buddies face to face and compete or just have a great time. Wand wars is an easy 10/10. I play a handful of games and I think this game rocks.

I play
Quake Live, Starcraft 2, Reflex, Counter-Strike Global Offensive, and recently Overwatch. Wand Wars is this calibur with quality game play. Plus the soundtrak is awesome. I just crank it on the house stereo haha.

reviewText:
It's one of these games with simple controls with which you can do a lot of ♥♥♥ kicking if mastered.

To be honest, it's a fun game. Loading it up and playing one quick match, or having some time and playing the story for a little bit longer, both are fun.
The music is good, the graphics are wonderful, the gameplay doesn't lag (and I am playing this on my good ol' laptop), so yep, I reccomend this if you think this looks fun.
Ah yes, also you unlock stuff by simply playing, but I think I also saw an option where you can turn that off.

The only downside for now is that there is no online play, and the dev(s) (it's one person coding all this after all) may just look into that, so it may be only a matter of time B)

reviewText:
Copy provided by developer for promotion consideration at http://isthereanydeal.com

I have to say I fell in love with this one pretty fast and the similarity to Lethal League really helped.
If you have some local friends go grab Wand Wars right now and have some really good time turning each other to chickens, smashing them with bouncy and speed-and-size-increasing orb of light and using special spells to turn the tables. You can even change some game rules.

Though, if you're buying this for the campaign only, it's good, a bit short and it's basically a story-based tutorial introducing you to the game modes and spells and building this I can't wait to play this with friends" feeling insde :)
And it's actually pretty challenging on hard mode. Saying that if only intend to play alone I would wait for a sale.

I am hoping this game gets the deserved attention and fanbase and some post-release support (some leaderboards
hoursPlayed: maybe we get an online multiplayer down the road?"

reviewText:
The backgrounds for this game are beautiful, but that's really all I have to say is good about the game.

Is the game good for it's simple concept?  Yes.
You try to catch a ball and fling it at other people.  There's a power-up in the middle that you can fight over.

Is the game worth the price asked?  Absolutley not.

I would be happy with the pricetag if there was at *least* online multiplater instead of only local.  When this games gets as low as $4, I'd be happy to pick it up.  As of now though, the game is seriously overpriced for what it is.
